p: Hybridisation events among non-closely related species are generally believed to yield events that are transient, and potentially affecting local population demography at most, because strongly maladaptive ( Rhymer & Simberloff, 1996; Malone & Fontenot, 2008). Nevertheless, there may be exceptions, whereby the effects of maladaptive processes propagate from population to community level ( Farkas et al., 2015). Moreover, as revealed by years of investigation on the hybridisation process in several animal taxa, including amphibians, new evolutionary pathways have been sometime opened by such rare and maladaptive events ( Arnold, 2006).
